A **halberd** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [two-handed](/wiki/Two-handed "Two-handed") [polearm](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") that is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and appears as an **angled poleaxe** when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification").

## Generation

In addition to random generation, general [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") and antique weapons outlets can sell halberds.

[Watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") and [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") may [be generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a halberd.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

The halberd has some of the best damage among the polearms, and has the highest average damage against [small](/wiki/Small "Small") monsters - it is also tied for the heaviest with the [lucern hammer](/wiki/Lucern_hammer "Lucern hammer") at 150 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum").

## History

The halberd is introduced with all other polearms in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Halberd](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Halberd "wikipedia:Special:Search/Halberd")***

[![Halberds.png](/images/thumb/8/8a/Halberds.png/300px-Halberds.png)](/wiki/File:Halberds.png)



A halberd (also called halbard or halbert) is a two-handed polearm that came to prominent use from the 13th to 16th centuries. A halberd is usually 1.5 to 1.8 metres (5 to 6 feet) long, and consists of an axe blade topped with a spike mounted on a long shaft, and may have a hook or thorn on the back side of the axe blade for grappling mounted combatants.

Early halberds were not too distinct from other types of broad axes or bardiches used all over Europe, until it began developing a more acute thrusting point in the late 13th century - hoops were used to secure the blade, and some variations also had spikes on the back. This early form of halberd is sometimes called a [voulge](/wiki/Voulge "Voulge") or swiss voulge, though there is no historical evidence supporting the use of these terms for this weapon. Later halberds would incorporate sockets into the blade in place of hoops, with back spikes integrated into the blade construction as a universal part of the design. The halberd was the primary weapon of the early Swiss armies of the 14th and early 15th centuries, and was relegated to closer combat with the addition of the pike to better repel knightly attacks and roll over enemy infantry formations; the German Landsknechte, who imitated Swiss warfare methods, also used the pike supplemented with the halberd, though the short sword (or specifically the *Katzbalger*) was the preferred side arm.

Halberdiers became less common in pikemen units used for ["push of pike"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Push_of_pike "wikipedia:Push of pike") warfare as that army's position became more defensive, and in general halberd usage by infantry became more rare and infrequent well into the mid 17th century. Halberds were still used by some low-ranking officers and sergeants until the 18th century, where it became a symbol of rank that lacked a sharpened edge and was instead used as an instrument to keep infantrymen in ranks correctly aligned with each other and level their muskets when aiming. The halberd has also been used as a court bodyguard weapon, and is still the ceremonial weapon of the Swiss Guard in the Vatican and the Alabarderos (Halberdiers) Company of the Spanish Royal Guard.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

[SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") adds [Reaper](/wiki/Reaper "Reaper"), a [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") halberd that is the guaranteed second sacrifice gift for [Yeomen](/wiki/Yeomen "Yeomen"), and has +5 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and +20 damage bonuses when pounding. This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the halberd has its weight reduced to 75 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum").

Various [Rilmani](/wiki/Rilmani "Rilmani") may be generated with a halberd: Ferrumach Rilmani may generate with a halberd of at least +1 [enchantment](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment"), Argenach Rilmani may generate with a [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") halberd that is at least +3, and Aurumach Rilmani are always generated with a large [concordant](/wiki/Object_properties#dNetHack "Object properties") [golden](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") halberd that is at least +4.

There are two artifact halberds:

- [The Crucifix of the Mad King](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Crucifix_of_the_Mad_King "DNetHack artifacts") is a neutral intelligent artifact that favors [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), and is the [crowning](/wiki/Crowning "Crowning") gift for neutral female [half-dragon](/wiki/Half-dragon_\(starting_race\) "Half-dragon (starting race)") Nobles. It is large-sized, made of [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal"), has +1 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and deals +1d10 dark damage. It can be safely enchanted to +10, and acts as a "living item" while wielded, having a chance per turn of lashing out at any hostile monsters within 2 squares of the wielder. It has three random effects when lashing out, and [invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") the Crucfix will cause one of these effects to occur immediately.
- [Heartcleaver](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Heartcleaver "DNetHack artifacts") is a chaotic intelligent artifact that is wielded by [Baphomet](/index.php?title=Baphomet_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Baphomet (dNetHack) (page does not exist)"). It grants +1 to-hit and double damage, and can be used in melee combat without penalty.

### NetHack Fourk

In [NetHack Fourk](/wiki/NetHack_Fourk "NetHack Fourk"), the halberd is one of the few polearms that is not removed.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the halberd is one of the few polearms that is not removed.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), frost salamanders have a 3⁄4 chance of being generated with a halberd.

A halberd can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining an [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe") and a [ranseur](/wiki/Ranseur "Ranseur") - it is the only polearm-skill weapon not to directly use a [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear") as a component item, though a spear can be used to forge a ranseur.

[Tempest](/wiki/Tempest "Tempest") is an [unaligned](/wiki/Unaligned "Unaligned") artifact halberd that can only be created at a forge by combining [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") and [Cleaver](/wiki/Cleaver "Cleaver").

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") retains Reaper from SLASH'EM and changes its [object material](/wiki/Object_material "Object material") to [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") so that it can be safely wielded by [elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") Yeomen.

All halberd details from EvilHack minus Tempest apply.

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for polearm](/wiki/Polearm#Encyclopedia_entry "Polearm").*
